text.p: These are the leading stories in the Algerian press on Sunday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia, standing the test of political pluralism, presents his three-party coalition government programme before the National Assembly (lower house) where 10 political parties and 11 independent personalities are represented.
- The government comes under the fire from the opposition on the first day of the cabinet programme debate in the lower house.

- (Islamist-oriented) Movement of a Peaceful Society (MPS) and (former ruling) National Liberation Front (FLN) promised to disown the government if Ouyahia does not rejig the cabinet programme. MPS and FLN are members of the cabinet with seven ministers each one.
- Opposition parties say the government programme lacks detailed figures and precise time limits to tackle the country's main issues.
- A "terrorist gang" cut the throats of 21 people in Medea overnight Thursday-Friday. Among the dead were five-month-old twin babies, four women and three elderly men.
- "Terrorists" slashed the throats of eight people in the eastern province of Tiaret overnight Friday-Saturday. They also flogged a man and then cut his throat at the same area.

- A "terrorist gang" set ablaze a bakery in Tizi-Ouzou province, east of Algiers, and stole the owner's car to punish him for his refusal to pay to the "protection-racket" run by the "terrorists" in the area.
- A homemade bomb killed between seven and 11 people in the southern town of Djelfa near a mosque shortly before Moslem Friday mass prayers.
- Security forces killed 18 "terrorists" south of Algiers in the past 48 hours.
- Bomb blast killed 10 people and wounded 20 in Djelfa.
